review_title: 5 star potential, 1 star reality:  still deeply  mired in dysfunction
pros:
Mission, (most) staff, flexibility, benefits: the IB has all the basic pieces in place to be a great place to work and make a difference in the world.

The new DG has set a vision for the organization that is inspiring and could make for a wonderful working environment and a highly functional, even groundbreaking organization. 

Entry-level and junior staff are benefitting from the organizational changes already.

As with the overall rating, the ratings below reflect current reality; the rating for the vision that has been presented would warrant 4 or 5 stars in most categories.
cons:
TL:DR - Key executive leaders remaining from the previous DG's tenure are paying flamboyant lip-service to the exciting new vision and transformative culture change, but continue to exhibit bullying, self-serving, incompetent and short sighted behaviours in their day-to-day activities and interactions with staff and each other. Change will be impossible so long as this continues.

----

Either incapable of understanding the implications and requirements of the new vision or choosing to use this moment of change as an opportunity to expand their fiefdoms, key executive team members consistently undermine their colleagues and are rapidly eroding the IBO's credibility from within. Bullying runs rampant and significant decisions are being made based on who can respond to emails the fastest or speak the loudest, rather than on collaborative, thoughtful consideration of complicated issues, drawing on staff expertise and using the approaches and tools inherent to the "new IB culture."

These same "leaders" are directly responsible for the failure of crucial long-delayed initiatives, some adding new items to long lists of their past disasters. Staff morale is plummeting as yet another round of vital projects falls apart with no acknowledgement from leadership that they take responsibility for the outcomes, no sign of the organisation holding them accountable for their repeated inability to deliver, and no indication that the IBO recognises these now clear trends of failure as signs of larger problems needing immediate attention. 

This failure of leadership is also impacting the flagship initiatives of the "new IB." One example is a recently launched global symposium, with the aim of engaging and listening to diverse voices, has been offered only in English, running counter to both the event's stated purpose and to a long-standing IB policy of always offering resources and services in the organisation's three working languages. 

The organisation remains hamstrung by the brain-drain that took place under the previous leadership (and continues to occur, albeit at a slower rate). There is little substantive subject/curriculum expertise among the staff, which is rapidly eroding the IB's core value proposition -- an unimpeachable, innovative set of curricula -- due to short-sighted, ill-informed decision making. Efforts are made to compensate, but there is a limit to how much any organisation can work around such deficits and how quickly experts can be brought in or contracted to make up for lack of internal expertise. Many other departments are also struggling due to a lack of institutional and subject-matter knowledge. Staff are well-intentioned and hard working, but in many cases, they don't know what they don't know, and the leaders from whom they are taking direction don't know either and worse, don't care to find out.

There is little opportunity for advancement from mid-level management upward. The organisation's new culture has not yet been brought to bear on staff advancement, and the process and priorities for pursuing and achieving advancement remain murky. Quite a few recent promotions were set into motion by previous leadership and many are not aligned with the newly set priorities of the organization.

job_title: Senior Global Role in The Hague
pros:
International atmosphere... The mission is truly attractive and there is an opportunity to truly see the world with the IB.
Nice people to work with along with very nice and comfortable settings.
cons:
Poor leadership! The Senior Leadership Team has not shown the willingness to act upon clear issues that have been factually laid out in front of them at several times.
Kissing up to the boss will get you much further than actually doing your job and placing the best interest of the IB first; so if you're the very political type, you should just identify the people that you need to kiss up to and you'll be fine. 
The IB has an educational business but at the end of the day, it is a business, so decisions need to be made by people who actually understand the business/financial implications of the decisions they make. Educational people are not business people, as much as they want to believe that they are.
As a responsible and engaged employee, it's tough to see all the money and resources wasted with very little accountability and consequences, pointing it out leads to being labelled a negative person.

job_title: Learning and Development Manager in The Hague
pros: The international culture, relocation package, mission and vision brought to life in schools across the world
cons: If IB students are looking for a future career somewhere that models the values of their education, they should keep on looking - because sadly they will not find the Learner Profile or spirit of inquiry living and breathing in the culture of the IB. Creative talented people are drawn in by the powerful (and externally visible) mission and vision only to find the day to day processes and senior leadership so uninspiring they either leave or stay and accept defeat. I am truly saddened that such an organisation cannot - and will not - recognise its shortcomings or take action (in true IB style) to practice what it preaches. A waste of talent, energy, time and worst of all - as a not for profit - money that it should be ploughing back into its products and services for schools around the world.

review_title: An organization with a powerful Mission that is changing itself for the better.
pros:
I've been at the IB for a year and a half. The IB has a high standing in the educational world. In the past, I believe that was combined with a slightly bureaucratic, stand-offish, status-conscious way of doing things, but that's definitely changing. Professionally, my experience so far has been rewarding. I think I can help improve things here in terms of bringing in an outside perspective - and I can honestly say that I have been challenged (and never bored) here.

The IB has an overriding Mission - "Education for a better world": everything the organization does is aimed to that end. This sounds simple, but the IB is not a simple organization, with a sometimes confusing complexity in its working structures. This is something the management is acting on, and there is a refreshing hunger for change in the organization.

For the most part, colleagues are open, friendly, hard-working and intelligent. Working conditions and benefits (overall) are good. It is a well-designed office in a good part of town - quiet, international, with good shopping nearby.

The new DG, Dr Siva Kumari, who joined shortly before I did, works hard to make it less hierarchical and process-driven. The leadership team supporting her are fairly new to their jobs. New, senior IT people are improving the infrastructure.

All in all, it's a time of change, with all the reactions you'd expect, internally and externally.

The main criticism is that salaries seem quite low - HR have an unshakeable grip on this and on job development - this may also be changing, because otherwise there'd be a problem to attract and retain the best.

Overall, I rate the IB highly as an employer with great colleagues, a strong and visionary DG, and a sense that they are looking for good, effective people who care about education and making a difference to the world.
cons:
Salaries seem slightly below average given the location and the sector.

Reward and remuneration may be worth looking at to make sure the IB can recruit and retain the best people.
